--- Foundations of Geometry ---
 Points, Lines, and Planes: Undefined terms forming the basis of geometry.
 Line Segments and Rays: Parts of lines with endpoints or one endpoint.
 Angles: Formed by two rays sharing a common endpoint (vertex).
 Angle Types: Acute (less than 90°), Right (=90°), Obtuse (greator than 90°), Straight (=180°).
 Angle Pairs: Complementary (sum 90°), Supplementary (sum 180°), Vertical, Adjacent.
 
 --- Logic and Reasoning ---
 Conditional Statements: “If p, then q.”
 Converse, Inverse, Contrapositive: Variations of conditional statements.
 Biconditional: “If and only if.”
 Deductive Reasoning: Uses facts, definitions, and logic.
 Inductive Reasoning: Uses patterns and examples.
 
 --- Proofs ---
 Two-Column Proofs: Organize statements and reasons.
 Flowchart Proofs: Visual diagram of logical reasoning.
 Paragraph Proofs: Written logical explanation.
 Postulates and Theorems: Accepted truths or proven statements.
 
 --- Parallel and Perpendicular Lines ---
 Parallel Lines: Lines that never intersect (same slope).
 Perpendicular Lines: Intersect at right angles.
 Angle Relationships: Corresponding, Alternate Interior, Alternate Exterior, Consecutive Interior.
 Transversal: Line intersecting two or more lines.
 Slope Criteria: Parallel (same slope), Perpendicular (negative reciprocals).
 
 --- Triangles ---
 Triangle Sum Theorem: Angles add to 180°.
 Types by Sides: Equilateral, Isosceles, Scalene.
 Types by Angles: Acute, Right, Obtuse.
 Exterior Angle Theorem: Exterior angle = sum of two remote interior angles.
 Triangle Congruence: SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, HL.
 Triangle Inequality Theorem: Sum of two sides has to be greator than the third side.
 
 --- Polygons ---
 Sum of Interior Angles: (n - 2) × 180°.
 Each Interior Angle (regular polygon): [(n - 2) × 180°] / n.
 Exterior Angles: Sum = 360°.
 Names: Triangle (3), Quadrilateral (4), Pentagon (5), Hexagon (6), etc.
 
 --- Quadrilaterals ---
 Parallelogram: Opposite sides parallel and equal.
 Rectangle: Parallelogram with right angles.
 Rhombus: Parallelogram with all sides equal.
 Square: Rectangle + Rhombus.
 Trapezoid: One pair of parallel sides.
 Kite: Two pairs of adjacent equal sides.
 
 --- Coordinate Geometry ---
 Distance Formula: √((x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²).
 Midpoint Formula: ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2).
 Slope Formula: (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁).
 Equation of Circle: (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r².
 
 --- Transformations ---
 Translation: Slides figure without rotation.
 Reflection: Flips over a line.
 Rotation: Turns figure about a point.
 Dilation: Resizes figure proportionally.
 Rigid Motion: Preserves size and shape.
 
 --- Similarity ---
 Similar Figures: Corresponding angles equal, sides proportional.
 Scale Factor: Ratio of corresponding sides.
 Triangle Similarity: AA, SSS, SAS.
 
 --- Right Triangles and Trigonometry ---
 Pythagorean Theorem: a² + b² = c².
 Special Triangles: 45°–45°–90° and 30°–60°–90° ratios.
 Trigonometric Ratios: sin = opp/hyp, cos = adj/hyp, tan = opp/adj.
 Inverse Trig: Find angle measures from ratios.
 
 --- Circles ---
 Parts: Radius, Diameter, Chord, Tangent, Secant.
 Arc Measure: Portion of a circle’s circumference.
 Central Angle: Equal to arc measure.
 Inscribed Angle: Half of intercepted arc.
 Circumference: C = 2πr.
 Area: A = πr².
 Sector Area: (θ/360) × πr².
 Arc Length: (θ/360) × 2πr.
 
 --- Area and Perimeter ---
 Rectangle: A = lw, P = 2l + 2w.
 Triangle: A = ½bh.
 Parallelogram: A = bh.
 Trapezoid: A = ½(b₁ + b₂)h.
 Circle: A = πr², C = 2πr.
 Regular Polygon: A = ½aP.
 
 --- Surface Area and Volume ---
 Prism: SA = 2B + Ph, V = Bh.
 Cylinder: SA = 2πr² + 2πrh, V = πr²h.
 Pyramid: SA = B + ½Pl, V = ⅓Bh.
 Cone: SA = πr² + πrl, V = ⅓πr²h.
 Sphere: SA = 4πr², V = ⁴⁄₃πr³.
 
 --- Reasoning, Proof, and Construction ---
 Constructions: Use compass and straightedge to create figures.
 Perpendicular Bisector, Angle Bisector, and Circumcenter.
 Centroid, Incenter, Orthocenter.
 Logical Proofs: Combine algebra and geometry reasoning.
 Coordinate Proofs: Use formulas to prove geometric facts.
